OVERLOOKED VALUE
The Bureau of Appointments, eampuS headquarters for student and post graduate employment, this week announced its
large interview schedule for the month of January.
In the few years the Bureau has been in existence it has
established firm contacts with many national and local business
organizations. Each year men from .these concerns come to
Homewood to interview qualified students who will be in search
of employment following graduation.
Until this year the response for these interviews has been
overwhelming. It happens now, however, that students who
expect to enter the armed forces upon graduation are no longer
interested in interviewing business representatives. This is a
mistake.
Any company that sends a representative to the campus cares
little about the draft or ROTC status of the students. Most all
organizations will hire approved men even if they expect to be
called to duty within a few weeks following graduation.
The student has only to gain from interviews with these men.
He could secure a job following graduation, even though it be for a
short duration of time. He will have promise of employment
upon his discharge. He will have an opportunity to make valuable
contacts with officials of various concerns and probably what is
more important. he will have gained much needed experience in the
methods and practices of commercial-ill:Aft-Viewing.
Any students who .can meet the qualifications for these interviews, which will be running from now, until Spring, should. take
advantage of them. Their cost is • but a few minutes of a day
and yet their net gain can be of infinite value.

STILL WORTHWHILE
The meeting this year of the annual convention of the Middle
Atlantic Region of the International Relations Clubs, scheduled
on December 27, 28 and 29 in Levering Hall, has been heralded
by the blaring of several big names which appear now to be
realistically and dimly distant. Justice William 0. Douglas will
definitely not make his appearance during the three-day assembly,
while there is some very, very slight chance that the delegates will
be treated to addresses by Dean Acheson and John Foster Dulles.
Those students who represented the Hopkins Club in last
year's congregation in Montreal requested that the convention of
the current year be held at Homewood because they felt that both
the delegations and our University would be benefited by the
arrangement. Plans have since been formulited which have
switched the focus of attention and discussion from the area of
Europe (treated at Montreal) to the area of Asia. A potentially
interesting, though not spectacular, schedule of debates and
speeches with a supporting slate of well-qualified speakers has
consequently been arranged.
Asia has been divided into three parts, which will form the
three basic subjects of the convention's work: China and Korea,
south-eastern Asia, and Japan. A separate panel of speakers has
been, and in some cases is still being, selected to dwell entirely on
each of these subjects. All three panels are to be formed of approximately five persons, professional men and presumably experts in
their fields representing the press, institutions of learning and the
State Department.
Although planned primarily for IRC representatives, this convention will be open to all those who are sincerely interested in
attending the sessions. It is, therefore, partially unfortunate that
the dates fall within the Christmas holidays, when tio many resident students will not be here. In spite of, and in some measure
because of, the lack of "big attractions," the conference gives
real promise of being successful.

West Point Conference Discusses
U. S. Foreign Policy hi Europe
By I. W ILLIA M ZA RTM A N
The writer was one of two
delegates to the Student Conference on United States Affairs, held
at West Point on December 5
through S. The other delegate was
Benjamin Sem Zartman participated on the integration of Europe panel.
About 120 representatives from
52 colleges gathered at West Point
last week to discuss American foreign Policy towards the Rimland
of Europe, that is, towards Western Europe.
Coming from as far as Oklahoma A .& M, the students presented, through conclusions drawn
from panel discussions, policies'for
four segments of the area in consideration. The panels considered
Anglo-American relations, the integration of Europe, special problems of the controversial nations,
and the peculiar situation of
United States leadership in world
affairs.
The delegates on the whole
seemed exceptionally well versed
In the topic of the conference,
which lasted four days. This was
the third such Student Conference
on United States Affairs sponsored
by the Military Academy; Hopkins
has sent delegates during the last
two years as well. The political
leanings of the delegates, in general, seemed to tend to the con-

servative side, which corresponds
to the trend analyzed by the recent contraversial article in Time
magazine.
'I'a riff Harriers
The students concluded that
the destiny and economy of England was more closely tied to the
United States than to Europe, except in purely European matters.
This, they explained, was not the
truism it appeared to be. Britain's
ties with the Commonwealth, plus
its necessary, if only psychological, aloofness from European internal Problems calls for a closer
Atlantic Union between the two
countries rather than the inclusion of Britain in any federative
scheme for Europe.
Tfie recommendations on the integration of Europe stressed more
the functionalistic approach than
the federative, for the group felt
that, finding no positive reason
for political unification, economic
and military unification was the
means to best accomplish the negative aims of defense. Tariff barriers were to be reduced, and
Schuman Plan and Benelux efforts,
as well as NATO and European
armies, encouraged. The group
recognized, however, that the ultimate aim of functionalism was
federalism.
In the matter of the controversial nations of the rimland, there

was as little agreement among the
student opinion as there is in public opinion. Spain was considered,
by a small majority, to be essen(Continued on Page 7)

OVERLOOKED VALUE
The Bureau of Appointments, eampuS headquarters for student and post graduate employment, this week announced its
large interview schedule for the month of January.
In the few years the Bureau has been in existence it has
established firm contacts with many national and local business
organizations. Each year men from .these concerns come to
Homewood to interview qualified students who will be in search
of employment following graduation.
Until this year the response for these interviews has been
overwhelming. It happens now, however, that students who
expect to enter the armed forces upon graduation are no longer
interested in interviewing business representatives. This is a
mistake.
Any company that sends a representative to the campus cares
little about the draft or ROTC status of the students. Most all
organizations will hire approved men even if they expect to be
called to duty within a few weeks following graduation.
The student has only to gain from interviews with these men.
He could secure a job following graduation, even though it be for a
short duration of time. He will have promise of employment
upon his discharge. He will have an opportunity to make valuable
contacts with officials of various concerns and probably what is
more important. he will have gained much needed experience in the
methods and practices of commercial-ill:Aft-Viewing.
Any students who .can meet the qualifications for these interviews, which will be running from now, until Spring, should. take
advantage of them. Their cost is • but a few minutes of a day
and yet their net gain can be of infinite value.

STILL WORTHWHILE
The meeting this year of the annual convention of the Middle
Atlantic Region of the International Relations Clubs, scheduled
on December 27, 28 and 29 in Levering Hall, has been heralded
by the blaring of several big names which appear now to be
realistically and dimly distant. Justice William 0. Douglas will
definitely not make his appearance during the three-day assembly,
while there is some very, very slight chance that the delegates will
be treated to addresses by Dean Acheson and John Foster Dulles.
Those students who represented the Hopkins Club in last
year's congregation in Montreal requested that the convention of
the current year be held at Homewood because they felt that both
the delegations and our University would be benefited by the
arrangement. Plans have since been formulited which have
switched the focus of attention and discussion from the area of
Europe (treated at Montreal) to the area of Asia. A potentially
interesting, though not spectacular, schedule of debates and
speeches with a supporting slate of well-qualified speakers has
consequently been arranged.
Asia has been divided into three parts, which will form the
three basic subjects of the convention's work: China and Korea,
south-eastern Asia, and Japan. A separate panel of speakers has
been, and in some cases is still being, selected to dwell entirely on
each of these subjects. All three panels are to be formed of approximately five persons, professional men and presumably experts in
their fields representing the press, institutions of learning and the
State Department.
Although planned primarily for IRC representatives, this convention will be open to all those who are sincerely interested in
attending the sessions. It is, therefore, partially unfortunate that
the dates fall within the Christmas holidays, when tio many resident students will not be here. In spite of, and in some measure
because of, the lack of "big attractions," the conference gives
real promise of being successful.

West Point Conference Discusses
U. S. Foreign Policy hi Europe
By I. W ILLIA M ZA RTM A N
The writer was one of two
delegates to the Student Conference on United States Affairs, held
at West Point on December 5
through S. The other delegate was
Benjamin Sem Zartman participated on the integration of Europe panel.
About 120 representatives from
52 colleges gathered at West Point
last week to discuss American foreign Policy towards the Rimland
of Europe, that is, towards Western Europe.
Coming from as far as Oklahoma A .& M, the students presented, through conclusions drawn
from panel discussions, policies'for
four segments of the area in consideration. The panels considered
Anglo-American relations, the integration of Europe, special problems of the controversial nations,
and the peculiar situation of
United States leadership in world
affairs.
The delegates on the whole
seemed exceptionally well versed
In the topic of the conference,
which lasted four days. This was
the third such Student Conference
on United States Affairs sponsored
by the Military Academy; Hopkins
has sent delegates during the last
two years as well. The political
leanings of the delegates, in general, seemed to tend to the con-

servative side, which corresponds
to the trend analyzed by the recent contraversial article in Time
magazine.
'I'a riff Harriers
The students concluded that
the destiny and economy of England was more closely tied to the
United States than to Europe, except in purely European matters.
This, they explained, was not the
truism it appeared to be. Britain's
ties with the Commonwealth, plus
its necessary, if only psychological, aloofness from European internal Problems calls for a closer
Atlantic Union between the two
countries rather than the inclusion of Britain in any federative
scheme for Europe.
Tfie recommendations on the integration of Europe stressed more
the functionalistic approach than
the federative, for the group felt
that, finding no positive reason
for political unification, economic
and military unification was the
means to best accomplish the negative aims of defense. Tariff barriers were to be reduced, and
Schuman Plan and Benelux efforts,
as well as NATO and European
armies, encouraged. The group
recognized, however, that the ultimate aim of functionalism was
federalism.

was as little agreement among the
student opinion as there is in public opinion. Spain was considered,
